text:
So I thought maybe we
could start quickly just by helping me get a sense
of who's in the background,

in the attendance. I know that's kind
of a mixed crowd. So how many people
here are technical?
OK. What about policy legal? And like business folks?

OK, cool. Great mix. So today, I'm going to be
talking about DAO liability.

I'd want to start by
talking about a concept

from this woman, Carlota Perez,
who's a Venezuelan economist.

And I think this is a
great analytical framework to take when you're discussing
crypto law and policy.

And I think what Carlota
does, in particular, is she identifies a cyclical
relationship between partly law

and technology. And the way that this
relationship works is with every technological
paradigm of the time,

there develops a legal
framework that is best adapted to that paradigm.

And what happens
over time then is that when the new technological
paradigm develops,

it is in conflict with the
prior legal framework that

has developed. And therefore, the
legal framework acts as an
exclusionary mechanism

that drives the development
of this new technology in the fringes.

So this is a little
bit of a deeper dive into Carlota Perez's framework. And you can see in the
bottom left eruption

is when this new
technology is born. And then there's a
period of frenzy,

which is where this technology
is developing, attracting a lot of capital, again,
still kind of in the fringes

of the regulatory framework. Then there's a turning
point, which is typically

brought about by
catastrophe of some sorts, some big event that forces a
realignment between the old, now

obsolete regulatory framework,
and the new technology of the day. And then that leads
to the golden era

where there's a synergy between
the both and a maturity. So my the thought
is that we are here.

And frankly, we might even look
at the events of last summer

leading up to FTX's collapse as
the big event that's potentially going to cause this realignment
between the regulatory framework
and the technology.

OK, so what are we going
to talk about today? I want to start by
going over the couple

of regulatory enforcement
actions against DAOs. Then I want to talk about
some of the private litigation

against DAOs. And once we have these couple
of examples on the table,

try to distill some themes in
what we can call DAO litigation

and talk about how that's
affecting DAOs and their members and what they can do
to protect themselves.

And I should have said
this at the beginning, but I very much welcome
questions and interruptions
and corrections from you guys.

So what is like my big point? My meta thesis here is
that we DAOs are basically

facing a wave of litigation that
could threaten their existence and operation in the US.

And that's because,
as we'll see, there are certain kind
of procedural advantages

that plaintiffs
have when suing DAOs that make it very
favorable for them to bring these types of claims.

And unfortunately, the
regulatory framework hasn't developed
to the point where DAOs are can be fully
recognized or protected
from their activities.

So we're going to start off by
talking about Ooki DAO, which

is notable because it was the
first regulatory enforcement action against the DAO and it
also was the subject of related

private litigation. So Ooki DAO was formerly
known as the bZx protocol.

Is anybody here
familiar with it? Yeah. So it's basically
like DeFi 1.0 version

of like a lending protocol. It allows you to trade assets,
go long, and get some leverage.

It was founded by a couple
of guys in the United States, and it didn't really exude a
culture of like compliance.

As we'll see later,
they advertised heavily,

like, there was no KYC. They ended up getting hacked. One of the developers was
phished and lost a bunch of--

ended up losing a bunch
of crypto in the protocol because he had the
private keys to it.
So what happened?

Sorry, yeah, this
is also a key point. Like many DeFi protocols,
it was developed

by a couple of
people in a company, and a developing company. And then later, they
issued a governance token

and basically allowed
the holders of that token to control certain admin
keys of the protocol.

They have this like
really unfortunate quote that the CFTC picked
up on and that I think has driven a lot of
the outcome of the litigation

where the founders are
basically saying everyone's getting sued around us, like
it's really unclear what

the regulatory framework
is, so we're just going to basically decentralize
as a regulatory arbitrage

strategy.  And it did not work
out that way for them.

So the first thing
that happened was that the CFTC sued the two
founders and the development

company, and settled with
them for a pretty modest fine, $250,000, which in CFTC terms
is like a slap on the wrist.

But it was a pretty
curious settlement because it basically found the
founders culpable for behavior

during two separate periods. The first period, the
CFTC said, you guys

were the owners of this company
that developed a protocol and then the protocol
basically allowed people

to trade commodities on margin. So they were talking about
Bitcoin and Ether specifically

and the fact that you could
have leverage on the protocol. And they said this is an
activity that is typically

only allowed to
be done by what's called a DCM or FCM, which
is like a highly regulated

intermediary that there's no way
like a crypto startup could ever become one.

So they found him
liable for that period. But then they said, you were
also liable for after the--

you guys did the governance
token drop and the DAO had some sort of admin key
control over this protocol,

you were also culpable
during that period.

So up to here, I
think, it was kind of like an aggressive
enforcement action,

particularly like that
finding them liable for that second period,
but nothing kind of out of the ordinary.

What I think really riled people
up was when they turned around

and concurrently also sued
the quote unquote, " DAO". So maybe to put it
out to the audience,

how would you
explain this behavior on the part of a regulator? If you already got the two
founders and the development

company, why would you go
ahead and sue the DAO after?

Sure. Chilling effect on
participation or to say that just because you're
a DAO does it mean

you're immune from the law. Yeah, so I definitely--
do think it had a chilling participation--

effect on participation? I don't know if
that was the goal. I think the goal was the
second point that you said. It's like in their mind,
they look at that quote

and they're like,
that says we're going to decentralize so there's
nothing to enforce against. And they're thinking,
like, if it's

illegal to run a
DCM as a company, well, sure it should be
legal to run it as a DAO. So in their mind, they
have this equivalence

of the role that a development
company and the kind of founders of this protocol have with
the role that a DAO has.

So yeah, they have this-- basically this whole
theory of liability is underpinned by
their conception

that there's a transfer
of control when the DAO token holders get some
admin rights to the protocol.

And then we have a quote from
the CFTC chair saying basically, like, this was so egregious
that we had to do something.

We couldn't just stand
by and do nothing. Yeah, please.

Are you saying that it was sued
by the-- they sued the DAO. Does that mean that the DAO
members themselves are culpable,

or there's no concept of like
limited liability here or? So that's one of the key issues
that we're going to drive at,

but I can just address it now. The critical point when
discussing liability of DAOs

is that they're
potentially assumed to be an unincorporated
association

or a general partnership. And that's kind of like
the default business entity that the law will assume.

If people get together to do
a business without forming like an LLC or a C-corp,
they'll just say, well,

you guys are general partners. And the real draconian
result of that

is that then any member of
that general partnership can be what's called jointly
and severally liable.

So if you're running
a partnership that creates $10 million in
liability and you're

the creditor to that or
an enforcement agency can pick any member and say
you owe me now $10 million.

And then that member
gets the right to go fight and ask for
recovery from the other members,

but good luck recovering
money from an anonymous frog on the internet.

So yeah, that was-- that's like the crux
of the issue basically.

And I guess a couple
of other points to tease out before we move. How do you serve a DAO?

They don't have offices,
they don't have addresses. So what the CFTC did, and this
almost sounds like a joke,

is they literally went on the
front end of the Ooki protocol. They clicked Help, and
there's like a little chat

thing that pops up, and they're,
like, here's the complaint. And then they also put it in
like the governance forum.

Legally, this created a bunch of
questions as to whether that's

like proper service, because
ultimately what can happen is you're holding any token
holder liable for that action,

like, are they really going
to get notice of this lawsuit? So a bunch of what
are called amicus,

so like people that are
third parties to a case, including first LeXpunK, which
is a kind of DeFi advocacy group

that was funded
from treasury of--

it wasn't this. It was the, I forget. I think it was Compound and
one other DeFi protocol. And then DeFi Ed Fund, as well
as two funds, two VC's Paradigm

and Andreessen, both filed
amicus briefs basically arguing that what the CFTC
had done here,

it didn't meet the bar
for like proper service. And we ended up
losing on that point.

And then, I guess, another
key point to tease out here is that when you're
saying that DAOs

are general partnerships or
an unincorporated association, you have to basically engage
in a line-drawing exercise

where you got to
figure out, all right, who exactly is part of the DAO?

What the CFTC said
was anybody that held tokens and voted even
once on whatever governance

proposal happened was
a member of the DAO. So then you can start
thinking about all these absurd hypothetical
situations where,

what if bought a token, voted
on a governance proposal to change the background color
of like the front end, now,

I'm like a general
partner and like running like an unregistered DCM? Or what if the proposal was,
like, do we want to run a DCM

and you say no? You still now voted on a
governance proposal and a kind of like dragged along.

So there's all these kind of
weird fringe cases that come up.

And this might be like a little
bit nerdy or too legally. But where we are procedurally
in the case was--

and this is still-- all these
cases are still ongoing. The judge has now
ruled that the Ooki

DAO was an unincorporated
association for the purposes of receiving process.

And he did that just
by basically going to the definition of
unincorporated association

in the California
code, saying there were two people,
more than two people. You guys all agreed
to form a business

when you receive these tokens. And they have a sufficiently
lawful purpose which

is to control this protocol. And again, the
quote in the bottom

highlights this
theme again, which is you can't evade
liability or responsibility

by decentralizing. So you here have
the judge saying the protocol itself
is unregistered
in violation of federal law. Somebody must be responsible.

So I think the key
from this last slide is just to note that
the ultimate liability

of the DAO and the members
has not yet been determined. So far, it's only at the point
of, has the service been proper?

So I think there's still like
a second part of this case where the merits are
going to be adjudicated.

And so far, the CFTC has
indicated in its briefing

and in oral arguments
that they really only want to enforce whatever judgment
they get against the DAO,

and I presume that
means like the treasury, but they're not going
to try to go screw

any individual token holders. But again, doctrinally,
that's where this could lead.

Yeah, two questions. Maybe up in front. Yeah, I'm curious to
know, how did they

establish jurisdiction in the
DAO provided it's centralized? So why does CFTC think
that they have jurisdiction

to regulate it and not another
regulator or authority elsewhere

in the world? Yeah, so the question
is on what basis did the CFTC find
that it had authority

to have this judgment against
the DAO given that potentially token holders all
over the world, right?

So that's a good question. It was briefed in the
amicus briefs a little bit.

And I think the--  there was a little anecdotes,
might be like too in the weeds.

But in one of the hearings, we
were basically arguing that.

We were saying, you don't
know if this the token holders are in France. Like, how are you
going to say that this is abiding by the French
service of process rules?

And then the CFTC lawyer
said, no, no, no, we know that the two
founders were in the US.

So then what the
judge ended up doing was ordering the CFTC to
serve the founders in the US

for purposes of
accepting this process

and they got like
this amazing response from the founders
lawyer, because, again,

like the founders
had already settled. So the lawyer was,
like, got your letter. As you know, we settle
this like a month ago

and part of the settlement
said that they could not be participating in
any more DAO activities

and were not authorized
to receive this process, so thank you. But I can't serve it. So I thought it
was like awesome,

and I was like hooting and
hollering when that came out. But the judge, again,
I think mostly driven

by this theory of equity,
of, like I can't just let them evade liability,
found that the process was OK.

I mean, the other jurisdictional
hook is the users, the US users were able
to access the protocol.

Was there a question back there? I guess kind of related, so
how do you not go to jail?

Do you just set up like-- do you set up the DAO, let's
say, in a overseas place

and then they just can't
send you something? So this is a good reminder to
give my disclaimer that I'm not

giving any legal advice. And the views here are
not the views of Paradigm.

So I'm trying to figure out how
to give you a satisfying answer.

So the question is,
how do you go to jail-- how do you not go to jail?

And basically, whether
offshoring the operations works.

So I'll try to
answer it this way.

The US regulators have an
amazingly expansive view of their jurisdiction.

Look at Avi-- they brought
a bunch of cases, basically.

If any of the products
are available to US users, even if that is by a US
user connecting through VPN,

like in violation of the terms
and conditions of the protocol, they will find that
enough to find you liable.

So I don't think it's-- you're not going to dissuade
them by being out of reach.

There was one amazing quote from
Arthur Hayes, the BitMEX founder

who was found guilty
of like AML violations,

where the government attached
as an exhibit to the complaint

his tweet that said, "I'm
incorporated in the Seychelles. Come at me, bro." So they really they don't
take lightly to that.

And the other thing
is like when-- but you're right. A lot of the projects like
at least knee-jerk reactions

are like it's so messy here. It's so risky that I'm
just going to go offshore. That doesn't really work, unless
it's truly an offshore project.

What I mean by that is that US
users aren't able to access it, even through VPNs, and it's
not controlled by a US person,

because there's a
lot of tax, I think, a big footfall at
that projects make is they don't consider the
tax implications of that.

And there's a lot of
tax rules like ECI, effectively connected income,
like PFIC, CFC controlled

foreign corporation laws. That basically mean that if-- they're designed to avoid
offshoring income to low tax

jurisdictions. So if you're found to basically
be controlling economic activity

outside of the US
from the US, the IRS will come get you and
charge you penalty fees.

So I guess the long answer-- the long-winded answer
is going offshore

is understandable reaction
to the uncertainty here, but it's not, in my
view, a foolproof

solution because
the regulators still think they have jurisdiction. And if you're
controlling it, you're

going to have tax issues
or regulatory issues. But yeah, I see a ton
of Cayman Foundations,

Panamanian Foundations, currency
trusts, every kind of cycle, there's like a new more
exotic flavor of it.

But I don't think it's going
to really stop regulators.

OK, so that's the CFTC. Now, I want to switch
gears a little bit and talk about the SEC.

And maybe I should have not
presumed understanding of this, but the CFTC is the
commodities futures regulator.

They regulate like
derivatives and they basically were created to regulate things
like pot bellies and oil futures

and stuff like that. SEC is securities land. And they're like been
the main antagonist

of the crypto industry. And there's also been
this interesting dynamic where they're basically both
vying for the opportunity

to be the main regulator of
the crypto spot markets, which if you think that
crypto is going

to be a huge part
of the economy, from the agency's perspective,
could be like a huge power grab.

So the SEC has done
a lot less on DAO specifically, but the
first thing much earlier.

So do folks here
remember the DAO hack? So this was the
slock at DAO that

was basically like a
VC fund that everybody was super excited about. It got hacked and led to the
fork between Ethereum Classic

and Ethereum. So a few weeks
after that happened, the SEC issued what it's
called like a 21 (a)

report, which is not
an enforcement action. It's just like a
guidance to the market.

And what they said was
basically the tokens in this DAO

were securities. And they met-- and
they were securities because they met the definition
of investment contract.

I'm sure everybody here is
familiar with the Howey test. So this was basically the first
salvo in that whole discussion.

And the point that they
made was even though every--

and sorry, I should say-- the Howey test is this test
designed to basically determine

when a arrangement
that could otherwise look like a
commercial arrangement really is a
securities transaction

and should be brought under
the umbrella of securities law and all the added
disclosures and liabilities.

And what it basically
tries to get at is if you're giving somebody
else money with the expectation

that that other person is going
to go away and do something else, and because
of their effort

you're going to get more money
back, then that is a security, like notwithstanding
what form it takes,

what the ultimate
object of it is. And what that means is that
the person that's taking money

should give the public
a bunch of disclosures and should be liable
if they lie about this.

So then the question is, what
happened to everybody voting in this?

Like there's not--
you're not really relying on somebody
if everybody gets to vote on what you're doing.

But what the SEC said was
basically the voting rights that the DAO token holders
had were very limited.

They focused on the role that
this basically like whitelist curator had who had the power
to admit proposals for the DAO.

And they said, since there's
this kind of gatekeeper personal role here that is
responsible with admitting

or denying any proposals,
you don't really have a full control of this.

And they also weirdly
said that because there were decentralized
and anonymous, it was going to be very hard for
the token holders to coordinate,

so therefore, they
couldn't really-- they had to rely on somebody. Was there a question back there?
No. Sorry.

So we didn't hear anything
about DAOs from the SEC until our friend Avi.

So are you guys familiar with
the Mango hack that happened a couple of months ago?

So this guy Avi
Eisenberg basically

did an oracle
manipulation attack on Mango markets, which is a
lending protocol in Solana.

And what he did is he
basically took a position that was collateralized
by Mango and then

put a bunch of bids
and trades on exchanges that fed the oracle
price to the protocol.

So that he pumped
up the price that allowed him to basically
use his collateral

to just wipe out all the
other assets in that protocol. And then when he
stopped manipulating

the price of Mango tokens, the
whole thing came crashing down. And then he owned up
to it because he's
like a CODIS law type of guy. God bless.

And he then got arrested
in Puerto Rico the day after Christmas or
something, and he

got sued by the DOJ,
the CFTC, and the SEC, all dog-piled on top of him.

And so focusing on the
SEC's enforcement actions

specifically, what they
said was Eisenberg violated the anti-fraud and
anti manipulation rules because the underlying
tokens were securities.

And again, this is kind
of like a DAO token that allows you to vote, not
too dissimilar to the Ooki DAO

tokens. And they said that the DAO was
an unincorporated business--

an unincorporated association,
so similar, again, to the Ooki formulation.

But I think one key
tension between the view that the CFTC holds and the SEC
holds, the CFTC is telling you,

you guys are all general
partners in this business because you're voting
tokens to quote

unquote "control" a
protocol, and therefore you're potentially
personally liable.

The SEC, on the
other hand, they want to try to argue that
they have jurisdiction so they need to find that the
underlying token is a security.

But as we discussed, general
partnership interest, because all the
partners are voting,

are often thought of
as not being securities because there's no third-party
there that you're relying on. You're all kind of
in this together.

So again, similar to what they
said in the initial DAO report,

they basically said that
yeah, you Mango token holders, you have some voting powers.

But you don't really
have voting powers because I guess not everybody
was able to make proposals.

They also said
that not everybody would be technologically
sophisticated enough to make a proposal.

So briefly, what was
then Eisenberg's defense? I mean it seems
like manipulation

pretty clearly, but why did
he think that he was not acting in bad faith?

I mean, he's like
a CODIS law maxie. And that seems silly to lawyers,
but there is admittedly a divide

into what from what the
crypto community or the more kind of extreme parts
of the crypto community

think is like fair game and what
the rest of society thinks is.

He basically said, hey, I
didn't steal anyone's password. I didn't impersonate anybody. The code was functioning
as it was designed.

I was just able to understand
how it would react better than the team.

I mean, I think,
he's kind of arrogant and I'm not surprised
that he got arrested.

But at the same time, I think
that we need people like Avi if DeFi is going to be able to
be hardened over time because--

so I don't know. I'm kind of conflicted
about people like him. Because he kind of taints the
whole space in a negative light

if he just was taking
advantage of just rules that aren't written there. I think it could
taint the space.

I think it could also
make it more resilient, make the applications
more resilient.

And what we want to do
is develop systems that

are able to coordinate
relationships without the need for relying
on the law to enforce those,

I'm kind of
sympathetic to his plea to kick the tires on everything.

I wouldn't suggest
tweeting about it or coming to Puerto
Rico for Christmas.
Was there a question back there? No such thing.

So where does that leave us? In the words of
Matt Levine, it's

like the worst of all worlds,
because you are similar enough

to shares that you are
dealing in securities but as you guys all know
like stock gives you

limited liability, but
you're also different enough that you're kind of
look like a partnership

and potentially are
a general partner. So not great.

OK, so that was basically the
big federal enforcement actions

against DAOs. And now, I wanted to
tick through a couple of the private ones.
How are we doing on time? 10 minutes. OK, I'll try to go quick.

And obviously what the
federal government is doing is directly impacting what
private litigants want to do.

So the first one
here is PoolTogether. Have you guys familiar
with this one?

This protocol? So it's like a no-loss lottery
where you would basically deposit ETH or crypto
in the smart contract.

The smart contract would then
like LP on Ave or Compound, and it would get that yield, and
it would basically raffle it off

to people. So you never lost your
principal and you got a chance at getting some
upside from the yield.

And the plaintiff in this case
was a self-described concerned

citizen who thought
that the crypto is like boiling the ocean.

So he bought like $12 worth of-- he got $12 of some stable coin,
deposited into this protocol,

and then sued every the
founders and all the investors, basically claiming
that they were acting

as a general partnership running
this unincorporated association, which was like an
illegal lottery.

And then this same
firm, over time, has now brought three different
class actions against DAOs.

And interestingly, you can see
how through that progression, they're like sharpening
their arguments

and also pulling in from what
the regulatory enforcement actions are doing.

So in this first one,
for example, they argue that all the partners-- all the investors
and the founders

are members in the
general partnership. But they interestingly
don't sue the quote unquote,

"partnership " or DAO. The next one was the private
litigation in the bZx case.

Again, this is the same thing as
Ooki, just like the class action version of it. And here, the
plaintiffs were people--

they were like agents that
had a bunch of money on Ooki and lost some of them like
up to $450,000 in the hack.

And then they said, you guys
were a general partnership running this business. You owed us a duty to
run it in a safe manner.

You breach that by letting
the dev get hacked.

And then this is the
latest one to be filed. This one was particularly
painful for me

because it named
Paradigm and it was filed the day after a holiday party.

So I was sipping a cup
of coffee with a headache trying to figure out what we
were going to do about this.

It was on a Friday too. And so what they
did here was they basically sued the
Compound DAO and like

a bunch of the big
named investors, and they said that it was
an unregistered offering of securities.

Interestingly, they focused on
their liquidity mining program as the actual offering.

Even though they didn't get any
plaintiffs that participated in that, the couple
of plaintiffs that they got were people
that got $10 worth of COMP

by like watching those videos
on Coinbase, which I think is hilarious.

But anyways, they again--  I guess there's not much
more to say about this one.

And all these cases are still
ongoing, and none of them have reached any resolution on
the point of whether a DAO is

an unincorporated
association, other than Ooki and the limited service context.

They plaintiff in the
suit, what is the goal? So this is-- the
underlying claim

is unregistered
offering of securities. And so when you're a plaintiff
in that you basically

are asking for what's
called a rescission, you're saying you sold me
something that should have been

registered but since
you didn't register it, I get the right to basically
put it back to you.

So it's almost like a put
right that you get at the end. Yeah? What do you think is
really behind these claims?

I. Don't see why anyone
should sue for $12

Yeah, interesting question. I can get pretty
conspiratorial about this

because class actions are very
expensive to bring forward. I think part of what
explains this frankly

is like a plaintiff's
law firm that is just being entrepreneurial and like
wants to make this their niche,

they also see it as a
big business opportunity if they end up
getting certified. So the way that
class actions work,

you'll have the
first lead plaintiff but then you'll certify a class. So it won't only be the
person that put $10.

That's just the person
that files the first suit. Then they will then
be like anybody that contributed to
this protocol ever

or in this period
gets to join in. But I have wondered
whether like there's some third-party financing here.
But I don't know.

And this is the latest fun. Patents trolls. So are you guys familiar with
like the patent troll industry

at all? So these are basically
companies that will buy up patents
and then just sue tech

companies for infringement. And it's like a pretty
basic business model. If it costs you less
to enforce the patent

then you get the payout,
then you make some money and you just try
to do it at scale. So a lot of these patents are
frivolous or patents are invalid

and like the lawsuits
are frivolous but just because it's a pain in
the ass to deal with, they end up squeezing
money out of people.

So publicly, there's
been one troll that has sued both
MakerDAO and Compound DAO.

They have this
incredibly broad patent that everyone
tells me should not be enforceable that basically
covers any off-chain data,

like any oracle data
getting pulled on chain. And they have now
sued both DAOs.

And again, they're making
their way down the process.

So I guess this is
another key point that I wanted to distill
from all these litigations.

So why I think this
is so dangerous is because DAOs don't respond. Because DAOs are typically
super disorganized,

they don't have a CLO. So when somebody sues
a, quote unquote,

"DAO" there's no real
institution there to respond. And because of this limited
joint and several liability

issue, if I'm a member
in a DAO, why the hell would I want to raise
my hand to defend this?

Because if I do it
and I lose, then I'm the first in line to
pay for everybody else.

So what happened is
this dynamic has come up where plaintiffs can just
file lawsuits against DAOs

knowing that no one's going
to stand up and defend them. They'll get score points
while like the other teams

the judge can't do anything
other than issue a default. That basically says there
was a proper lawsuit

and nobody showed up to
defend it, so you lose. And then the plaintiffs-- this
hasn't happened yet but this has

to be the end goal-- they get that
default in one hand and then they go find the DAO
member that has the most money

or is the most visible. And they go try to
enforce it on them.

So it's a really
shitty setup for DAOs. OK, so what are some other--

STNY. But I think over time,
especially as these cases start

to proceed against individual
members that are not in the US, these questions of

going to become much more

The service issues too. So far, the plaintiffs have
survived the service challenges.

But again, I think that as
these cases move forward towards individual

going to be more
defenses for that.

So I think the main
question is, are DAOs some sort of

One key way to try
to analyze this

is if you think

still be decided.

I think a lot of what's

can find the most

now becomes, who's in?

What do you need
to do to be part of this general partnership? Is it voting? Is it just holding a token?

Is it making a
governance proposal? Is it passing some
sort of proposal?

So I think that's still unclear. And then another-- this might
be like nerdy and technical--

but if the underlying
theory of liability this

is a general partnership
where all partners are jointly and severally liable,

hard to get private plaintiffs. For example, in the

And then some more

which they'll try to wash

And I don't understand the

For example, CFTC chair

So what can DAOs do
to protect themselves?

There's no kind of
perfect solutions. I've done a fair
amount of research into DAO wrappers, which
are basically legal entities

that DAOs can form. You guys might have heard
of like the Wyoming DAO laws

or we talked about the off
shoring structures earlier. So I think it's an
interesting area there's

a lot of experimentation. There's no perfect fit. And a lot of these
corporate forums, especially the more traditional ones,
introduce a lot of restrictions

into the operation
of the entity. So if you're a DAO
LLC, you can't just

become a member of that
LLC by buying a token. You would have to sign
a legal agreement.

There's a lot of
issues with anonymity. You can't necessarily
preserve anonymity in a lot of these
corporate forms.

And then I think people
also get very confused with the offshore
structures because a lot

of these structures
are what's called like ownerless entities,
which are basically like a trust structure.

But it doesn't necessarily
give limited liability to the token holders because the
token holders aren't members.

They're not shareholders
of this entity. This is just a trust that's
set up to basically benefit

some sort of purpose. People are thinking about

I don't think they've

And then third
party organizations. So there's been a lot of amicus

On the patent troll matter
specifically, there's been some pretty interesting
patent-specific solutions.

We've been trying to coordinate
with a organization called Unified Patents, which exist
pre-crypto to fight patent

trolls. And what they do
is basically they create zones where
they will admit members

who will cross-licence
technology to each other and then put money in a pot. And then unified
patents will just

sue any troll that messes
with any other members. So it's basically a
deterrence mechanism

by just increasing
the cost of any troll will have in like trying to
enforce against these people.

So it's like they don't kind
of negotiate with terrorists type of strategy.
